ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We discussed the concept of wonder, why it is important to children to learn, and how that does or does not carry into adulthood. This was essentially a child development class as well as possible intervention class.
I really got to discover a passion for developmental psychology. Very fascinating and cutting edge material
science behind the joy of exploration and discovery. perspective into child development research and wonder.

I gained more insight into the mechanisms of wonder, and in what ways might wonder decrease or increase / be preserved as we age. It teaches readings from multiple interesting studies, from past to present. We strongly engage in these materials through classroom discussion.

I learned a LOT about random things about the world and to wonder more, and putting words to phenomena in every day life. For example, children need multiple examples, mechanistic understanding is cognitively demanding, and even preschool-age children want informative explanations and selectively retain answers they receive... and they'll retain explanations better than non-explanations.
An ability to really see the questions behind mundane objects and processes. I literally wonder about things more

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I wish the units were more structured. I found the readings and class discussions interesting, but I didn't always track how we were covering material more broadly/in a more compartmentalized way.

I found the structure of classtime to be engaging with the nice mix of wonder presentations, discussion, and debate.
very engaging class discussions and great readings.
I think it was a very good course. Discussion might be improved in a non-zoom format.
Phenomenal lecturer so passionate and the readings were really interesting. Group work was always interesting. I wish we could have a bit more debate some weeks, but it was still interesting!
Great structure, wonderful instructor, clear assignments and feedback

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!! Especially if youve never explored developmental psychology before!
Highly recommend  probably my favorite course this semester.
YES. I constantly felt inspired by what I learned and it's inspired me to keep learning new things after graduation!

Yes!! Take this course both for the content and for the way its taught - Professor Keil is a gem and will literally show you a new way to think about the world. I took this as a graduating senior and Im so glad I did, it changed the way I think about curiosity and wonder and being a person

Maybe -- I liked the course content and the case studies with other students in the course but I don't think I gained all that much from in-class seminar discussions. I did like the final project and I think I developed a deeper understanding of wonder, but I don't think Prof. Keil's teaching style fit with how I learn best. It is an interesting topic and I liked the class overall, but seminar discussions were not what I would have expected.

extras.title: CGSC 427 01/PSYC 427 01/PSYC 627 01 - The Rise and Fall of Wonder
